abstract: Dell said it would offer networking equipment that was built with nonspecialized semiconductors and an open-source operating system, as opposed to the highly proprietary gear.
snippet: Dell said it would offer networking equipment that was built with nonspecialized semiconductors and an open-source operating system, as opposed to the highly proprietary gear.
lead_paragraph: Dell said it would offer networking equipment that was built with nonspecialized semiconductors and an open-source operating system, as opposed to the highly proprietary gear and software from like Cisco Systems and Hewlett-Packard. While that is unlikely to be a huge business soon for Dell, it lends credibility and muscle to what has been a growing effort to dislodge these incumbents through cheaper, easier-to-build equipment. If Dell and others can do that, a result would be lower costs at the large data centers run by Google, Facebook and large banks and companies. Cheaper networking could also make the Internet even more ubiquitous.

headline.main: Open-Source System to Be Offered by Dell
headline.print_headline: Open-Source System To Be Offered By Dell

abstract: Though not a total financial loss, the announced sale of the smartphone unit for $2.91 billion, less than two years after Google paid $12.5 billion for it, is a sign of fits and starts at the company in the mobile age.
snippet: Though not a total financial loss, the announced sale of the smartphone unit for $2.91 billion, less than two years after Google paid $12.5 billion for it, is a sign of fits and starts at the company in the mobile age.
lead_paragraph: Larry Page, Google’s co-founder and chief executive, likes to talk about “big bets” and “moonshots.” But the thing about moonshots is that they can crash into earth.

headline.main: After Big Bet, Google Is to Sell Motorola Unit
headline.print_headline: After Big Bet, Google to Sell Motorola Unit

byline.original: By Claire Cain Miller and David Gelles

abstract: Breaking down the admittedly messy math for the original Motorola deal shows that Google didn’t exactly lose nearly $10 billion on that transaction.
snippet: Breaking down the admittedly messy math for the original Motorola deal shows that Google didn’t exactly lose nearly $10 billion on that transaction.

headline.main: Did Google Really Lose on Its Original Motorola Deal?

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced
